title: Unit 1: Using Objects & Methods->Topic 1: Intro to Objects

blocks.content:
1. Open the new VS Code repository.
  2.   Create a new class/java file named RectangleRunner and copy/paste this code.
  3.   Create a second class Rectangle and copy/paste this code.

blocks.prompt:
Open the RectangleRunner class and note that it can be directly executed using the run arrow:

DO NOT RUN RectangleRunner BEFORE RUNNING THE Rectangle CLASS

Now open the Rectangle class; Try to run it.  note that it can't be directly executed.


Why can’t we execute the Rectangle class?
blocks.key:
The Rectangle class has no run button and cannot be directly executed because it has no main method.

See below that there is, in fact, no public static void main(String[] arg) method in the Rectangle class

blocks.content:
The reason for this is that the Rectangle class isn't designed to be executed directly, but is rather designed to be used to create objects for use in other places, such as in the RectangleRunner class, which does have a main method which executes.  Inside the main method of the RectangleRunner class, it uses the Rectangle class to make Rectangle objects and it calls methods on those objects.


**Note. Once you run RectangleRunner and then try to run Rectangle, VS Code will automatically resolve the conflict if you trying to run a class without a main method so it will look like you are running Rectangle but the IDE is switching to RectangleRunner for you

﻿

blocks.prompt: 2. Find the "constructor method in the Rectangle class

subQuestions.prompt: a.What do you notice about how it’s named?
subQuestions.key: The constructor has the same name as the class itself:  Rectangle

subQuestions.prompt: b.What does the constructor do?
subQuestions.key: It is a special method that gets called using the new keyword to create new Rectangle objects, like in the RectangleRunner class:

blocks.prompt: 3. Jump back to the RectangleRunner class.

subQuestions.prompt: a.What keyword (in orange) is used to create two different Rectangle objects?

b.This code:   new Rectangle(5, 6) calls the constructor method of the Rectangle class, passing 5 and 6 as “actual parameters” into the method.  Look at the constructor again in the Rectangle class;  what does the 5 represent?  What does the 6 represent?  How can you tell which is which?
subQuestions.key: 5 and 6 are actual parameters get passed into the constructor in the order listed so 5 is the length and 6 is the width

blocks.prompt:
4. Execute the RectangleRunner class and view its output.

﻿ Lines 6 and 10 of RectangleRunner are examples of “calling a method” on a particular Rectangle object:


rect1.printArea();


rect2.printArea();


Look at the output, then go to the Rectangle class and find the printArea() method.  How does the method calculate the area?

5.  In the RectangleRunner class, create another Rectangle object named rect3.  Give it a length and width of your choosing.  Then call the printArea() method on your new object.  Run the code to test that it works.


Copy and paste the line(s) of code that you wrote below:

6.  Try changing the values passed into rect3 to two doubles, such as a width of 6.5 and length of 10.5.  What happens and why do you think that is?  Hover your mouse over the red squiggly in VS Code to read about the error.


Is it a syntax/compiler error, or a runtime error?


Put the int values back to eliminate the error.
blocks.key: It gives a syntax/compiler error (red squigglies mean auto-compile failed) because the Rectangle constructor is looking for two int parameters, and you are trying to pass in doubles (and doubles can't be converted to ints)

blocks.prompt:
7. Go into the Rectangle class and add a new method, printPerimeter(), which calculates and prints the perimeter of the Rectangle, similar to area.  Start the method with "public void" like printArea() -- we will talk about what these words mean later.


Then test your method by going to RectangleRunner and adding code to call the new method on each of the Rectangle objects (rect1, rect2, rect3).  Confirm the output is what you expect.
8.  If you had to guess, what do you think public means?  What about void?
blocks.key:
public means you can call the method from a different class in your project; if you make it private, it won't work and VS Code will say "has private access" and the code won't compile (try it!).

void means the method returns no value (we will learn about this soon)
